title: Tuesday, 16th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Here we are, then.

BE

Best start with the huge news from the oil world, I guess.

BE

11:03 am
BE

The Gatwick Gusher!

BE

And there's not just a sign. Oh no ....

BE

There are also some pipes.

11:04 am
BE

BE

Full slideshow here: http://www.ukogplc.com/page.php?pID=85

BE

Which is of course to mark the news that Horse **** is flowing

11:05 am
BE

Basically, they had to put a straw in the ground and it's coming out like a torrent.

BE

The Horse Hill-1 well has flowed on test at an initial instantaneous rate in excess of 700 bbl/d through a 1-inch choke, in an approximate mix of 50:50 oil to water. The well was then choked back to 32/64-inches resulting in a steady early oil rate in excess of 460 bbl/d over a further seven hour period, in an approximate mixture of 99% oil and less than 1% water

UK Oil & Gas Investments PLC (UKOG:LSE): Last: 1.91, up 0.514 (+36.71%), High: 1.94, Low: 1.88, Volume: 178.26m
11:06 am
BE

Here's WH Ireland to sell you it's highly significant for the Horse **** asset.

BE

We note that today’s news is highly significant for the Horse Hill asset as it is the first ever flow test in the Lower Kimmeridge limestone interval within the Weald basin and provides proof that, moveable oil exists. Further we note that the flow test results exceeded managements internal expectations. We look forward excitedly to the final results from the other two intervals. We leave our Target Price at 5p unchanged in the interim and reiterate our Buy recommendation

BE

Hey, totally off subject .....

11:08 am
BE

I was reminded of this excellent post from many years ago, when bulletin boards hadn't turned into distractions for people who struggle with the concept of reality.

BE

http://boards.fool...dbook-6373903.aspx

BE

The Mining Promoter's Handbook, via Motley Fool.

11:09 am
BE

(And thanks to Lorcan for reminding me of it a few weeks ago.)

BE

Rule No 7

Always show photographs of planes and helicopters in the annual report. I don't know why, but everyone does.

BE

Clearly, that's off subject, as it's about miners not oil. No relation to Horse **** whatsoever.

11:10 am
undefined
BE

So I guess we need to mark the other news in oil.

BE

Saudi Arabia has provisionally agreed with Russia to freeze oil output at January levels, in a co-ordinated move to reduce a supply glut and shore up prices.

After more than 15 months of opposition to unilaterally cutting oil supplies, Saudi Arabia’s powerful oil minister Ali al-Naimi said the agreement between some of the world’s major producers to freeze output should be enough to stabilise the market, which has been hit by a 70 per cent slide in prices

The announcement followed a closed-door meeting in Doha between Opec powerbroker Saudi Arabia and Russia, the largest exporter outside the cartel, as well as Venezuela and Qatar. News of the meeting only leaked late last night, surprising oil markets and sending prices up by as much by 6 per cent on Tuesday morning.

11:11 am
BE

http://www.ft.com/...-98e7feb46f27.html

BE

Brent up about 12% yesterday on the hopes that Saudi's appearance at this rogue meeting was going to result in a cut.

BE

Which logic says always looked highly unlikely.

11:12 am
BE

As UBS says ........

BE

We remain sceptical consensus could be achieved between OPEC members, let alone nonOPEC producers, and that higher prices might only incentivise short-cycle U.S tight oil
producers to increase production. However, voices calling for an output cut are
growing louder, c.f. UAE last week, and with concerns over forward demand in the
global economy a policy shift cannot be ruled out entirely.

BE

Brent live is $33.80, come back from $34.05 since we started.

BE

That means we're a bit slower than usual, because it actually hurts to type.

11:15 am

It seems a sensible idea to rattle through some movers.

BE

11:16 am
BE

First up, Shell retaining most of its gain in spite of oil turning negative.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 1,569, up 28.5 (+1.85%), High: 1,607, Low: 1,566, Volume: 5.74m
BE

Which I think is on Goldman's push.

11:17 am
BE

We have removed the Not Rated designation from RDShell and add it to the
Buy List with a 12m target price of 1805p/€23.5/US$52.5 (B/A/ADR). The
stock has underperformed the sector 1% since the BG deal announcement.
In our view, the acquisition has lowered RDShell's position on the cost
curve, while increasing resource potential and capex flexibility. Gearing is at
levels similar to peers, and we believe the long-term LNG supply contracts
will provide support to earnings. RDShell has the highest dividend of the
peer group, a low decline upstream business and significant capital and
cost flexibility which it will be highly incentivised to utilise, in our view.

Catalyst
We see four key drivers of outperformance: 1) Successful execution of the
disposals program to maintain gearing at sustainable levels. 2) The
demonstration of further capital flexibility and the delivery of synergies and
operating cost savings. 3) The long-term supply contracts remaining in
place in the LNG market, ensuring profitability in integrated gas, particularly
if the oil price moves higher. 4) A recovery in the oil price to bring the
company back to a more sustainable cash flow position. We currently
estimate that the oil price should recover to US$62/bl Brent in 2017.

Valuation
Our 12 month target price of 1805p/€23.5p/US$52.5 is based on the sector
average multiple of 7x 2017E EV/DACF. The stock is trading on 32.6x/13.2x
2016/17E P/E and 8.4x/6.3x 2016/17E EV/DACF

undefined
BE

(@BBOC: comments get held in a "pending" zone and are approved eventually. But not always live. Nothing's lost. Though I recognise it's a bit frustrating in this live context.)

11:18 am
BE

On Anglo......

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 364.80, down 28.25 (-7.19%), High: 423.10, Low: 360.00, Volume: 8.38m
BE

Numbers are rubbish. As in, rubbish.

11:19 am
BE

Headline's slightly better than expected but the headline's irrelevant.

BE

Disposal programme is scaled up, as had been leaked last week.

BE

Good morning, welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this.

11:21 am
BE

Kumba now on for a sale or IPO.

BE

Minas Rio's being held onto for three years, the suspicion being that it can't be sold without the proper licences.

BE

In terms of the turnaround plan, there's a lot of sellside saying "jam tomorrow"

11:23 am
BE

Which feels a bit unkind. I mean, what option does Anglo have apart from jam tomorrow?

BE

A rights issue to fund cash-burning mines in the hope of metals prices recovering?

BE

One of those might still arrive, of course, depending on how the disposal programme goes.

11:24 am
BE

Here's Cazenove.

BE

Anglo American's FY’15 underlying EPS of 64c/sh is -8% JPMe (-2%
consensus), whilst -$0.9bn FCF is weak vs -$0.6bn JPMe. The restructuring
strategy evolves to shrink AAL to a core portfolio of Copper, Diamonds &
PGMs, which we estimate generates $2.0-2.5bn 2016 EBITDA on spot. This
more aggressive plan aims to shrink net debt from $13bn at YE’15 to ~$6bn
medium term, by increasing the disposal target to $3-4bn in 2016 & raising
2016 cost savings by $0.8bn (vs Dec CMD) to $1.9bn. This is a more
aggressive roadmap to reduce leverage to ~2.5x, but is still reliant on asset
disposals and AAL remains a minimum two year restructuring, in our view.
Targeted ~$10bn YE’16 net debt will be 4-5x core EBITDA, leaving minimal
headroom if prices fall further. We also remain sceptical on execution, not
least since disposals are unlikely to be coveted by peers and deals to date have
been underwhelming. Targeted $6bn core net debt and $2.0-2.5bn EBITDA
would be equivalent to a $12-15bn EV (6x EBITDA multiple) or $6-9bn
equity value for core vs AAL’s $7.5bn current mkt cap.

BE

 FY’15 EBIT in-line, non-operational items drive EPS miss: $2,223m
operating profit was essentially in-line with JPMe $2,227m although a small
beat (+3%) vs. Vuma consensus. Underlying earnings, however, of $827m
($0.64/sh EPS vs. $0.69/sh JPMe) was -8% vs. JPMe and a small miss (-1%)
vs. consensus. In terms of the specific operations, coal was the highlight,
generating EBIT of $457m, +45% vs. JPMe and +33% vs. consensus, whilst
De Beers ($571m, +5% vs. JPMe) was also stronger relative to our forecasts.
Iron ore, platinum and copper were 7%/14%/30% weaker, respectively,
relative to our forecasts. “Other” operating cost items of $64m came in well
below JPMe $109m, helping bring operating profit in-line with JPMe.
Working down the P&L, net interest expense of $489m was higher than
JPMe $278m, leading to the weaker underlying earnings performance.

11:24 am
BE

 Balance sheet & cash flow, FCF turns negative: -$1,114m FCF post
minorities was worse than JPMe -$934m and implies -$1.1bn FCF in H2.
CFO pre-working capital was $4.5bn (-1% vs. JPMe), although the working
capital performance was soft, generating a $220m outflow in FY’15 against
our forecast of +~$200m, resulting in CFO post w/c of $4.2bn, -11% vs.
JPMe and -14% once accounting for weaker dividends from associates as
well as higher cash tax and interest paid. Capex of $4,253m came in 6%
below JPMe $4,538m and gave net debt of $12,901m (in-line with JPMe
$12,914m) for gearing of 37.7% vs. JPMe 35.0% and 32.8% as at Jun’15.

BE

 Guidance largely unchanged: the key change to production guidance is at
Minas-Rio, where output has been trimmed to 15-18Mt in 2016E vs. last
guidance of 18-21Mt (JPMe 18.0Mt); medium-term production has also
been reduced by 2-3Mt over 2017/18E, whilst the FOB cash cost has been
lowered to $26-28/t over the first 22 years (JPMe $23.4/t). FY’16 production
guidance remains unchanged elsewhere. Group capex in 2016E reduced a
further $0.2bn to “

BE

$3.8bn impairments in line with guidance: AAL has taken $3.8bn of pretax writedowns in H2’15, $0.7bn on Rustenburg, $0.7bn on platinum assets, $0.6bn on Snap Lake, $0.5bn on Sishen, $0.4bn on coal assets, $0.3bn on El Soldado, $0.2bn on manganese assets and $0.3bn related to loss on disposal of Anglo American Norte, in-line with the $3.7-4.7bn guidance given at the CMD in December.

 Cost cutting increased by $800m: AAL increase cost-cutting target by
$800m compared to what was announced at Dec’15 CMD taking it to
$1.9bn in 2016.

 Retain UW: We continue to see long-term value in AAL, as evidenced by
our base case P/NPV of 0.69x, but this hinges on a recovery in commodity
prices over the medium term, specifically in PGM and diamond prices and
execution of significant restructuring. Expectations of weak prices in the
near term leave AAL on 7.1x/6.5x spot EV/EBITDA in FY’16/17E, with a
spot FCF yield -1.9% in FY’16. We remain UW and continue to highlight
risks around the balance sheet in 2016.

11:26 am
BE

And Shore.

BE

Full-year 2015 financials dire, if slightly ahead of expectations; iron ore and Atlatsa sacred cow on the chopping block; no details on Amplats funding plans. AAL’s full-year 2015 financials were dire, albeit ever so slightly ahead of both our expectations and that of consensus.

Falling commodity prices (AAL’s basket price was down 24% on 2014) meant that revenues were markedly down at US$20.46bn (2014: US$27.07bn), as was underlying EBIT of US$2.22bn (2014: US$4.93bn). These and US$5.7bn (post-tax) of impairments resulted in an attributable loss of US$5.62bn (2014: loss of US$2.51bn). Consensus was for revenue of US$20.56bn and a net loss of US$6.08bn.

Despite various cost-savings initiatives and asset disposals, net debt was flat on 2014’s US$12.9bn – and indeed, up on July 2015’s US$11.9bn (which had been flattered by the receipt of US$1.6bn from the sale of the Lafarge Tarmac interest) – albeit slightly lower than guidance of US$13.0-13.5bn. The company noted that undrawn facilities and cash totalled US$14.8bn as of end 2015, albeit with near-term debt maturities of US$1.6bn in 2016 and US$2.6bn in 2017.

AAL also put more flesh on the portfolio restructuring plan originally outlined in December 2015. There wasn’t as much detail as we would have liked, and we would preferred to see announcements of actual disposals rather than more disposal plans. That said, we noted the following:
· Bulk Commodities no longer core: The focus is now on “De Beers, PGMs and copper”, whereas AAL had previously said that it would focus on: De Beers, Industrial Metals (including platinum and base metals), Bulk Commodities (iron ore and coal). Indeed, AAL explicitly said that it is now considering “options to exit [the Kumba iron ore operations] at the appropriate time, including a potential spin-out”. Disappointingly, the Minas-Rio iron ore white elephant will remain for at least 3 years (at which point options will be assessed), we presume because that AAL has decided that it is unsaleable without having secured the licences required for the full ramp-up.

· Atlatsa sacred PGM cow on the chopping block? PGMs have been elevated to a separate group, but we were disappointed that no mention was made about funding for this segment. AAL did say that assets not identified as part of the long-term core portfolio would be “reviewed to determine the optimum path to realise shareholder value”. We noted that the Atlatsa joint venture was not amongst those named for said portfolio. In the past, the cash-hungry Atlatsa had been viewed as a sacred cow on which AAL’s BEE credentials rested, but it now seems to us that this sacred cow might end up on the chopping block after all.

· Non-core disposals target upped to US$5-6bn: Unsurprisingly, given the above, the target for the disposals has been increased to “$5-6 billion by end of 2016”, of which US$3-4bn is expected in 2016 (US$2.1bn having been announced or completed in 2015).

Meanwhile, capex is expected to be

BE

.... less than US$3.0bn in 2016 (25% down on 2015); in 2017, it is to be US$2.5bn. AAL is to focus on stay-in-business expenditure, but the company was careful to reassure that “future performance will not be jeopardised for short term cash flow gains”.

11:28 am
undefined
BE

And now we're having system problems.

BE

\o/

11:29 am
BE

Still, we'll abide.

BE

What else is there?

BE

Investec downgrade StanChart two days after upgrading.

11:30 am
BE

Valuation, unsurprisingly.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 418.90, down 34.15 (-7.54%), High: 453.40, Low: 417.88, Volume: 3.58m
BE

After recording a fresh 21st Century low of 387p on 11 February, Standard Chartered has rallied hard – up 17.2% in just 2 working days, to within 2% of our (unchanged) 460p target price. We don’t think that much has changed. As such we now are forced, somewhat hastily, to recommend that investors take profits (or cut losses). We downgrade from BUY to HOLD. On 0.5x 2015-17e tNAV Standard Chartered remains “optically cheap” but our (unchanged) RoTE forecasts of 0% in 2015e, 0% in 2016e and 4% in 2017e offer context.

11:31 am
BE

This is Ian Gordon, of course.

BE

The fact that Standard Chartered continues to trade below its 465p November 2015 rights price is, for us, merely a footnote in history. We happen to believe that Standard Chartered’s capital position will now prove adequate, supported by significant ongoing balance sheet de-risking initiatives. Indeed we forecast that the CET1 capital ratio will strengthen from 12.9% in 2015e to 13.9% in 2017e. It is the weak earnings outlook which constrains our enthusiasm.
As discussed in our reports, Are we there yet? (14 Jan) and, How much misery is now priced in? (12 Feb), our primary concern was and remains revenues. Our (unchanged) sub-consensus forecasts anticipate a 14% YoY decline to $15.7bn in 2015e, and a further 8% YoY decline to $14.4b in 2016e, with very limited relief on the cost line. Standard Chartered’s own guidance (November 2015) is for 2018 costs to be only marginally below 2015.
We think that the outlook for impairments remains highly uncertain, with extreme volatility in the oil price seemingly driving sudden short-term moves in sentiment and/or expectations. We forecast 2015e to be the peak year.
In the light of (very) recent share price performance, we downgrade to Hold (from Buy). Our 460p RoE-g/CoE-g-derived target price remains unchanged.
We think investors have ample opportunities to participate in any extended sector/market recovery via stocks offering much greater certainty. We see better value in Aldermore (Buy), Barclays (Buy), HSBC (Buy), Lloyds (Buy), OneSavings (Buy), RBS (Buy), Shawbrook (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy).
Standard Chartered is due to report its FY15 results on 23 February 2016.

undefined
11:32 am
BE

This ADT deal's just crossed the tape.

BE

ADT TO BE ACQUIRED BY APOLLO GLOBAL AFFILIATES FOR $42.00/SHR

BE

$15bn value.

11:34 am
BE

“This transaction represents a highly attractive premium for ADT’s shareholders,” said Naren Gursahaney, President and CEO of ADT. “We’re proud to have strengthened the quality of our customer base, improved service and retention, and extended our leadership in innovative solutions such as our ADT Pulse platform and our new Security-as-a-Service offering, ADT Canopy. By combining Protection 1 with ADT, we will be better positioned to expand the breadth and depth of the services we offer to our customers throughout the United States and Canada.”

“The combined company will be a market leader with a powerful brand and scale resulting in an enhanced overall customer experience,” said Timothy J. Whall, President and CEO of Protection 1, who will be the CEO of the combined business following the closing of the transaction. “In addition, Protection 1’s robust commercial presence will speed ADT’s expansion into the commercial sector supported by increasing commercial sales and technical skills across a well matched national footprint.”

BE

.......... None of which says they do burglar alarms.

BE

Which is what they do, right? Or am I getting confused?

11:35 am
undefined
BE

On Vodafone, which was mentioned earlier.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 209.06, down 0.395 (-0.19%), High: 210.00, Low: 208.00, Volume: 15.55m
11:36 am
BE

It's unavoidably kinda dull.

BE

JV .......

BE

And not a precedent for other markets.

11:37 am
BE

Deutsche incoming.

BE

Vodafone and Liberty Global (LBTY) are to merge their Dutch operations, creating a 50:50 owned JV. The transaction is intended to strengthen the combined Co. as a competitor in the Dutch market where Vodafone has struggled to offer convergent products and LBTY is keen to achieve owner economics in mobile (as evidenced by the acquisition of KPN’s Belgian asset, Base). Both Ziggo and Vodafone brands will be maintained.

BE

The combined Co. targets synergies of €3.5bn (NPV) of which €280m annual run-rate opex and capex savings by year 5 (€2.5bn NPV post integration costs of €350m). VOD will inject cash of €1bn and JV will target leverage of 4.5-5.0x (3.7x pro-forma) and distribute excess cash to shareholders (4.7x would see Vodafone recoup its €1bn top-up). VOD believes the deal to be FCF enhancing from the 2nd year post deal closure (i.e. FY 18/19), despite de-consolidation of asset. Deal completion is expected by end-2016 and is subject to the usual regulatory approvals which we believe should be forthcoming.

11:37 am
BE

VOD maintains the deal is continuation of a market-by-market convergence strategy and that a deal with LBTY in The Netherlands has limited read across to other markets. The market was recently disappointed that talks with LBTY weren't more wide-ranging but in Holland, Vodafone had much less favorable routes to market than elsewhere with the situation complicated (according to press reports) that another mobile asset is also for sale. This JV could lead to more co-operation between VOD and LBTY over time, but standalone, is a small positive (i.e 50% of €3.5bn synergies at no extra net cost).

undefined
BE

Okay, sorry folks. I need to go lie down somewhere dark.

11:41 am
BE

So we're going to be shutting early today. It's half term, which means numbers in the office are at barely functional levels.

BE

Thanks for your time and patience today. Back tomorrow, assuming I'm still alive by then.

BE

Farewell bulk, essentially.
